theverge.com  (WEB - en-US)

A website that covers technology, science, culture and transportation.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

TheVerge.com is owned by Vox Media, a digital publishing company that has several other specialty sites, including the explanatory site Vox, technology site Recode, food site Eater and sports blog SBNation.com. Vox Media's investors include NBCUniversal and several private equity firms, including General Atlantic and Accel Ventures.The site also makes money from advertising and sponsorships.

Content

The Verge defines itself as a "multimedia effort to examine how technology will change life in the future for a massive mainstream audience." The site features breaking news on the people, companies, innovations, politics, and big issues in the worlds of tech, science, transportation, and culture. It has a longform section that dives deeper into those issues with personal essays, and other in-depth features. The Verge also relies on video for its storytelling, and has a YouTube channel featuring interviews, new tech reviews, and shows.

Credibility

All staff members must follow the ethics policy, which states that "earning and keeping the trust of our audience is, and always will be, at the core of The Verge’s mission." The policy outlines the importance of independence, accuracy, and the wall that must divide editorial and advertising. All advertising is clearly marked. Sponsored content is identified as "presented by," with the company name listed.

The site’s corrections policy, published on the site, explains how stories are updated with a notation if content is inaccurate. The site may remove the entire piece and replace it with a version that omits the error, or clarify a developing story.

The Verge has won several Webby Awards, including five in 2013 for best writing (editorial), best podcast, best news app, best visual design (function) and best consumer electronics site.

Transparency

The site’s list of editors is easy to find and features short biographies and contact information for editors and reporters. The Verge lists its investors on the site and states none have influence on the content. Company ethics policies require that stories pertaining to any major investors should disclose the relationship.

History

An editor and several top staffers at Engadget, a technology news and review site, left Engadget in 2011 to form The Verge, partnering with SBNation.com, a network of sports blogs. The two sites formed the company Vox Media and created several other specialty sites.
